  • Philips Award August 1999
  • Notice of and Extra ordinary General meeting
  • Call for nominations to PCG committee for 1999/2000
  • Notice of the PCG AGM 1999

Physical Crystallography Group News - EGM and Call for Nominations

An Extraordinary General Meeting of the Physical Crystallography Group of the Institute of Physics (IOP) was held on Wednesday 27th January 1999 at the IOP. There was only one Agenda item, the proposed change of name of the PCG of the IOP to the Structural Condensed Matter Physics Group. The meeting was chaired by the Vice-Chairman of the group, Professor J. Finney. The arguments for the change of name were outlined and correspondence, both for and against the name change, which had been received by the Secretary, was read out. The proposal was put to the vote. 10 members voted for the proposal with three abstensions (Vice-Chairman of PCG, Secretary of PCG and the BCA President). Accordingly, the name of the group will henceforth be the Structural Condensed Matter Physics Group in its dealings with the IOP. We shall remain the Physical Crystallography Group of the BCA.


Call for Nominations to the PCG Committee

Nominations are required for the following offices:

  • Chairman from October 1999
  • Vice-Chairman from October 1999
  • Secretary/Chairman from October 1999
  • Two Ordinary Members from October 1999*

*Members of PCG may care to be reminded that Dr. S.Kilcoyne of St. Andrews University and Dr. J. Cockcroft of Birkbeck College, London were co-opted to the Committee to help out during 1998-1999. Also, please note that members of the PCG Committee are required to be members of the IOP PCG/Structural Condensed Matter Physics Group.

Please send your seconded nominations for the above to the PCG secretary,
Dr. P.A.Thomas, Department of Physics, University of Warwick, Coventry CV4 7AL.

Tel. 01203-523354 Fax. 01203-692016 E-mail: phrve@warwick.ac.uk

Pam Thomas
University of Warwick

1999 PHILIPS PRIZE

The announcement of the 1999 Philips prize award to Mark Harris, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, was made during the Closing Ceremony at the IUCr XVIII in Glasgow. It was given for his work in the field of magnetic frustration and, in particular, for his work in the area of magnetic pyrochlores. Magnetic frustration has been known to occur in these materials for over 40 years. Mark Harris and his co-worker Steve Bramwell were the first to explain correctly the way in which frustration occurs. In addition, Mark Harris has linked the ideas of magnetic frustration in a pyrochlore ferromagnet to the ordering of protons in ice coining the term "spin ice" recently discussed in Nature 399 311-2 (1999)
